title: A Multi-center, Randomised, Open-label Study to Evaluate Convenience and Safety of Change in the Mode of Administration of Rivastigmine (From Capsules to a Transdermal Patch) in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This study used two doses of rivastigmine transdermal patch (5 cm\^2, 10 cm\^2) to establish the feasibility of 2 switch schedules (with transdermal patch one-step dose titration or without dose titration) from rivastigmine capsules (3 mg bid (bis in die, twice a day), 4,5 mg bid, 6 mg bid) to rivastigmine transdermal patch and to assess safety, tolerability, convenience, and caregivers preferences of rivastigmine transdermal patch versus capsules.

groups.title: Rivastigmine Patch (4.6 mg/Day Switch to 9.5 mg/Day)
groups.description: Rivastigmine administered transdermally via patches at increasing doses (1 patch/day of 4.6 mg for the first month, changing to 1 patch/day of 9.5 mg for the remaining two months).

groups.title: Rivastigmine Patch (9.5 mg/Day)
groups.description: Rivastigmine administered transdermally via patches at a constant dose (9.5 mg/day for the 3 months of treatment).

groups.title: Rivastigmine Capsules (6 mg to 12 mg/Day)
groups.description: Rivastigmine administered orally, following the same regime as prior to randomization (doses between 6 mg and 12 mg/day), which remained unchanged throughout the 3 months of treatment.

groups.title: Total
groups.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Patients Who Had a Gastrointestinal Adverse Event (AE) at Any Time During the Study
outcomeMeasures.description: Gastrointestinal adverse events (including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea) were coded using the medical dictionary MedDRA v11.0 and the number of patients who suffered an AE were described by system organ class (SOC) and preferred term (PT).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population included all randomized patients who received at least one dose of the study medication.

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Patients With an AE Involving the Skin (Local Tolerance) Recorded Over the Course of the Study Period (Patch Groups Only)
outcomeMeasures.description: Adverse events involving the skin included urticaria, pruritus, erythema, and pigmentation disorder. Only the groups administered rivastigmine transdermally via patch were analyzed. The adverse events were coded using the medical dictionary MedDRA v11.0 and the number of patients who suffered an AE were described by system organ class (SOC) and preferred term (PT).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population included all randomized patients who received at least one dose of the study medication.

groups.title: Rivastigmine 4.6 mg/9.5 mg Patch
groups.description: Rivastigmine transdermal patches at increasing doses: Application of one 4.6 mg patch every day for the first month of treatment and thereafter daily application of one 9.5 mg patch for the next two months.

groups.title: Rivastigmine 9.5 mg Patch
groups.description: Rivastigmine transdermal patches at a constant dose: Application of one 9.5 mg patch every day for the whole treatment period.

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Patients With at Least 1 AE of Any Kind Recorded During the Period of the Study.
outcomeMeasures.description: Adverse events were coded using the medical dictionary MedDRA v11.0 and the number of patients who suffered an AE were described by system organ class (SOC) and preferred term (PT). They were also tabulated by severity, relationship with study treatment, and action taken.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population included all randomized patients who received at least one dose of the study medication.

groups.title: Rivastigmine Patch (4.6 mg/Day Switch to 9.5 mg/Day)

outcomeMeasures.title: Overall Caregiver Satisfaction With Treatment
outcomeMeasures.description: Caregivers were asked to rate their overall degree of satisfaction with the Alzheimer's disease treatment on a scale of 1 to 5 (1 "Very good" - 5 "Very poor") at the end of the study (Month 3). A higher score indicates less satisfaction.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population included all randomized patients who received at least one dose of the study medication.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in the Total Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) Score From Baseline to Month 1 and Month 3
outcomeMeasures.description: The Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) was used to evaluate the patient's cognitive status and how it progressed over time. The 35-point version used in this study was made up of five sections: orientation, fixation, attention and calculation, memory and language, and constructional praxis. The total score for each patient was obtained by adding the score from each of the above sections. The individual receives 1 point for each correct answer. The total score can range from 0 to 30, with a higher score indicating better function. A positive change score indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population was made up of all the randomized patients who had taken at least one dose of the study medication.

certainAgreement.otherDetails: The terms and conditions of Novartis' agreements with its investigators may vary. However, Novartis does not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Any publications from a single-site are postponed until the publication of the pooled data (i.e., data from all sites) in the clinical trial.

drug: rivastigmine (Exelon) — transdermal patch and oral capsules
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is rivastigmine given as capsules or a transdermal patch. Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used for symptomatic treatment (improving cognitive function and activities of daily living) in Alzheimer's disease, not a disease-modifying biologic or small-molecule aimed at amyloid/tau pathology. citeturn0search5turn0search1

Act: Key details extracted from the trial description — switching patients from rivastigmine capsules (oral dosing) to rivastigmine transdermal patch (two patch sizes/doses); primary outcomes were feasibility, safety, tolerability, convenience, and caregiver preference. This corresponds to administering a symptomatic cognitive-enhancing cholinesterase inhibitor via a different delivery route. Supporting literature shows the patch and capsule formulations are used interchangeably to provide symptomatic cognitive benefit, with the patch offering tolerability and convenience advantages. citeturn0search2turn0search4

Reflect: Classification check — by the provided category definitions, rivastigmine is a symptomatic cognitive enhancer (cholinesterase inhibitor). The trial compares modes of administration (capsule → patch) and assesses convenience/safety rather than targeting underlying Alzheimer pathology (amyloid/tau) or treating neuropsychiatric symptoms specifically, so the correct category is 'cognitive enhancer'. citeturn0search6turn0search1

Web search results used: 1) Rivastigmine review/clinical summary (PMC article summarizing rivastigmine's symptomatic efficacy and patch vs oral formulations). citeturn0search5 2) Cochrane review summarizing rivastigmine benefits and noting patch may reduce side effects vs capsules. citeturn0search1 3) PubMed caregiver-preference/IDEAL trial data showing caregivers prefer patch vs capsules for ease and convenience. citeturn0search2 4) Alzforum summary of patch vs capsule trials and approvals. citeturn0search4 5) Therapeutic review discussing rationale and advantages of the rivastigmine transdermal patch. citeturn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests rivastigmine (oral capsules vs transdermal patch), a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases cholinergic neurotransmission to provide symptomatic cognitive benefit in Alzheimer’s disease. This intervention modulates neurotransmitter signaling rather than targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, or other disease-modifying pathways. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Act: From the description: drug = rivastigmine (Exelon) in capsule and transdermal-patch formulations; purpose = compare mode of administration, safety, tolerability, convenience and caregiver preference for a symptomatic cognitive enhancer. Because rivastigmine acts by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase (enhancing cholinergic neurotransmission), the best CADRO match is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (neurotransmitter system modulation). Supporting clinical comparisons and caregiver-preference data are reported in the IDEAL trial and systematic reviews. citeturn0search2turn0search4turn0search3

Reflect: The classification aligns with CADRO definitions: the study is not targeting amyloid, tau, ApoE/lipids, inflammation, proteostasis, vasculature, etc., nor is it a diagnostic/non-therapeutic trial. It evaluates a symptomatic cholinergic enhancer delivered by different routes — a neurotransmitter-system intervention. Therefore D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is the appropriate category. Key supporting evidence (efficacy as symptomatic treatment and better tolerability/caregiver preference for patch) is cited. citeturn0search1turn0search8

Web search results used: 1) Cochrane review: Rivastigmine for Alzheimer’s disease (summary of symptomatic benefit and patch vs oral tolerability). citeturn0search1turn0search3 2) IDEAL caregiver-preference/patch vs capsule substudy (Neurology / PubMed). citeturn0search2turn0search4 3) PubMed summaries and trials comparing tolerability and safety of patch vs capsules. citeturn0search8turn0search5
